Mary Kelly is sending along to you today a file of
some 67 job applicants. Most of them have filled out the form
Mary sent them, so rate as currently available, at least so
far as we know. One point that I felt your people and Mary might
discuss is how you propose to keep them current.
She also raises the question as to how we should
handle the letters that come in from time to time asking about
opportunities;. In the past she has simply mailed them a form.
Would you like for her to continue that, or to simply acknow¬
ledge the letter and then forward it to you?
As I mentioned tc you before, we have people drop
in from time to time and she has handled them in the same way,
that is, had them fill out the form. I think we will probably
^ continue to do this if for no other reason than to sa/e the time
of our other people who otherwise would have to sit and listen
to the pitches. But we will tell tbu m, at the same time, to get
in touch with you and to send their papers to you.
As you can see from examining the file, we have
never really been in the personnel business, but were limply
trying to pull the pieces together and treat people who con¬
tacted us in an orderly way until such time as you were in
position to run recruitment programs, training schools and
all the things that are needed. We will look to you for real
service.
So, good luck and please be assured again that we
will cooperate with you in every way possible to make a success
of the venture. Let us know what we can do.
Cordially,
Robert R. Mullen
Executive Director
